title: Why Nancy Pelosi's political gamble over Trump impeachment is not guaranteed to pay off
text:
If you wanted evidence of just how huge a political gamble Nancy Pelosi has taken by launching impeachment proceedings against Donald Trump it could be found on Wednesday.

Away from the fevered activity on Capitol Hill, a poll released by Quinnipiac University – one of the country’s most trusted pollsters – gave an insight into what the rest of America has been thinking.

When asked whether Mr Trump “should be impeached and removed from office" just 37 per cent of those surveyed said yes. By contrast, 57 per cent said no. That is a 20-point gap.

Yes, the polling was done a few days before Ms Pelosi, the Democratic House Speaker, pulled the trigger on impeachment proceedings on Tuesday. But it is consistent with most past polls.

Up until this week the country, despite everything Mr Trump has been through – most notably the Russian election meddling investigation – has been against impeachment.

It is something of which Ms Pelosi has been all too aware. Throughout this year she has repeatedly cautioned against the move, saying public support is not there and it could inadvertently help Mr Trump, letting him play the victim.

So what changed? Firstly, the Ukrainian scandal arrived. Democrats believe that Mr Trump’s attempt to get a foreign leader to investigate his main political rival at the next election – Joe Biden – is clear and simple enough to have cut-through with voters.

Secondly, Ms Pelosi’s caucus shifted. For months now the majority of the 235 Democrats in the House have backed impeachment. But this week the figure started shooting up. By Tuesday around 160 of the 235 backed the move, including many moderates. Ms Pelosi risked a backlash if she did not act.

And yet the reasons why Ms Pelosi has been so hesitant to push for impeachment in the first place remain.

She has repeatedly argued that the Democrats will defeat Mr Trump next year by focusing on policies like healthcare, widely credited with winning the party the House majority in 2018.

Yet she has now set Washington on a path that will ensure Mr Trump’s behaviour in office – and whether it is worthy of a president – remains front and centre for much of the run-up to the November 2020 vote.

In the past, Ms Pelosi has insisted that impeachment must be done on a bipartisan basis to succeed. After all not just the House, which the Democrats hold, but the US Senate, which is controlled by the Republicans, need to vote for impeachment for it to be binding.

There has been no President in the history of our Country who has been treated so badly as I have. The Democrats are frozen with hatred and fear. They get nothing done. This should never be allowed to happen to another President. Witch Hunt! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 25, 2019

But there is little evidence of that so far. On Wednesday Republican congressmen – or at least those who did not evade the cameras – defended Mr Trump’s call with the Ukrainian president. They will have known their voters remain full square behind the president.

Ms Pelosi’s great gamble is that this time it is different, that the Ukraine scandal will finally convince Americans impeachment is necessary. Given the president’s success at playing the “witchhunt" card to date, however, that is no sure thing.
